ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Global context for how Shakespeare's plays have existed and permeated into different cultures.  Elthis course is equally literature analysis as much as sociological analysis.  NOT your typical Shakespeare's course and that's the best part about it.

I learned about the intersection of race, gender and Shakespeare, whose scholarship and performance have been dominated by white men. We read four plays, every single of which I thoroughly enjoyed. Although I am skeptical of some adaptations, most of them are well-taught and makes me think about Shakespeare in a different light.

how to question the place of works like Shakespeare in the canon, how to analyze Shakespeare, how to analyze what Shakespeare adaptations add or how they respond to Shakespeare or create something new and 'classic' of their own

I developed a greater understanding of how Shakespeare was used to colonize several places, including India, as well as how many people have used Shakespeare's work to tell their own stories. I learned a lot about some of Shakespeare's most popular plays, and the modern adaptations.

How to read Shakespeare as a timeless work and the specific ways that many of his plays still apply in the modern day. Recommended for anyone with an interest in Shakespeare, is in my opinion the one course about the classics that is still absolutely necessary.
knowledge of the nuances of Shakespeare and adaptations of his plays in regards to race, gender, and class
I think one of the most valuable insights I gained was in how adaptations work as well as how to question what the Shakespearean canon can provide.
I gained a deeper understanding of Shakespeare and how race, gender, and colonialism plays an vital part in it.

I learned a bit about how Shakespeare gets adapted and appropriated into modern contexts. For a course that focuses on close readings, I felt like I got more confused about how to analyze texts as the semester went on. A lot of my learning from this course came from additional readings that my TA and Prof. Ramachandran recommended as I wrote my papers.
This course opened my mind to the possibilities of studying not only Shakespeare but all "Classic" texts.
a knowledge of histories, controversies, and complications inherent in the reading and performance of Shakespeare and adaptations of Shakespeare

This class was extremely beneficial in comparative analyses of multiple mediums of work. In comparing multiple adaptations of Shakespeare across many mediums, the class helped strengthen writing skills and skills in formulating analysis.

There was a nice background in history, specifically the colonial history of Shakespeare and the usage of works as vehicles of colonization in the British Empire. Prof. Ramachandran really just knows her shit on a different level for context on Shakespeare's works and helped connect the text of the works and adaptations to the historical context extremely well.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths: flexible assignments, great amount of material to dive into, Dr.R is a gift to Yale and the world and I beg you to take a class with her before you graduate.


Weakness, sometimes we didn't go as in depth into some readings,

Strengths: the professor is very understanding, material is interesting, we use Discord to share our thoughts on readings which turned out to be great.
Weaknesses: I wish that the professor and TA talk more about the text rather than spending much of the lectures/sections touching on background information and critical reception

amazing syllabus with rich works, all sorts of different adaptations. a class to become cultured not just in Shakespeare but in global film, texts. Professor is fantastic. one of the best courses i've taken at yale. weakness is that short assignments and even the modified Discord prompts can feel like a chore.

Strengths: Professor Ramachandran gives a ton of options when it comes to assignments, some of which are creative and really allow students a break from the grind of straight critical analysis. Prof is also very chill. Huge plus.

I thought this class was an incredible opportunity to engage in well-known texts in a different and critical way. While I struggled with the reading loud (as a non-English major), I really enjoyed what we read, and the pacing of the course made everything very doable.

This class was so informative and engaging! It was really interesting and I learned a lot. I would say the pace is a little quick, but that may have been more due to the covid-impacted schedule of the semester than anything else.
Loved how the discord group added to afterclass engagement. Felt like the general weaknesses were due more to the unfortunate covid situation than the course design itself.
very interesting material, though it is very easy to get lost and lose focus from topics of race and gender

I think that the content and lectures were really helpful and insightful. My discussion section was also very good, I think that being able to flesh out ideas more thoroughly helped me think of better easy topics as well as different ways to look at Shakespeares work and their adaptations. 

As for weaknesses, I think that the discussion sections were a bit short so I could not fully develop some ideas.

Strengths: The content was pretty interesting, and analyzing different forms from novels to movies kept me pretty engaged through the term. 

Weaknesses: While I felt like Prof. Ramachandran and the TAs were understanding and their words certainly reflected their kindness, the many assignments of the course made the semester very difficult. The workload was a lot more than I anticipated. I put in a lot of effort into my papers and small assignments, and as the semester went on, I dont think it got much better. We all became more exhausted, and we did get multiple options to replace our final paper. But I dont think that helped much. All the work and grades and assignment just really stressed me out a lot over the semester.
This course has a really great syllabus, and the lectures are incredible. I honestly can't think of a way to improve it.
Professor Ramachandran is an excellent lecturer and professor all around. Her lectures are extremely engaging and she was extremely receptive and helpful in office hours.

This course is extremely strong in its connection between the original text of Shakespeare and the adaptations of his works, and more importantly, asking and answering the questions of why Shakespearean works are so frequently chosen as the basis for adaptation. The class delved heavily into understanding the canonical nature of Shakespeare and provided really interesting analyses of the works with focused passage readings and incredible lectures with lots of detail. The professor was so spot on and her care for students shone through. The themes addressed in the class of race, religion and gender were very topical but not approached in a very trite way. The analysis was nuanced and provided many different angles of interpretation to the larger questions in the class.

Weaknesses were few and far between but a major one for me was the course's lack of close reading of Shakespeare's works. While the course did largely focus on adaptation, I felt as though there could've been more analysis of the original text. When we did close reading, it was very helpful and informed the adaptations and the plot of the Shakespearean plays but I felt there could've been more analysis.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Virtual learning is hard.
Discord turned out to be a great tool for me to interact with my peers intellectually

not sure I liked the Discord for a class setting since I would prefer to compartmentalize my schoolwork apps vs my leisure/entertainment apps. would not recommend Discord in in-person setting because getting an overload of notifications can be anxiety-inducing on a regular basis, but to add another app on top of that can feel like an intrusion of personal/social media space by school. perhaps an alternative is Canvas discussion posts.
I loved that we used discord and created a very casual and engaging space to have conversations - MUCH better than reading responses on canvas.
I think Dr. R's breakout room prompts were very successful.
The discord group was a nice addition. It really helped foster a sense of community. Would recommend for any course even after things return to offline teaching.
discord as a platform was foreign to me before this course so I would've preferred if discussion posts were on Canvas instead
Virtual lectures are difficult to stay engaged in, but the discussion sections during helped add some sections that were more easily digestible.

I think that weekly discord posts graded in completion is a much better option than the three short assignments. My engagement with the material was better with a low stakes weekly response than a graded short assignment. Plus, it was far less stressful.

I am glad that the lectures were live, because otherwise I might not have had the motivation to watch them (simply because watching recorded lectures is draining.) I think that my experience would have been better if my section had started at a later time in the day, because I wasn't in Eastern Time and I often woke up five minutes before section began.

The lecture worked for me given how engaging and brilliant Professor R is. Section was a little less engaging, but its hard to maintain engagement in sections in zoom. I personally would have preferred an option to do another short paper rather than the few short discord posts, but it was a nice way to try and adjust to helping students during the pandemic.

I thought that the instructors did the best they could've on this one. Virtual learning is what it is and there really wasn't anything more that could've been done. What can be improved is just having the class in person.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: YES!!!!!! Especially if Dr. Ramachandran is teaching it again.

This is not a traditional Shakespeare class and Shakespeare is certainly not the expertise of the professor. Nonetheless, I think that everyone is remotely interested in Shakespeare should take it as we address some very relevant issues, especially surrounding race, in the second half of the course.
yes. don't take Shakespeare's place in the canon for granted. this class gives you the opportunity to question it, with the company of classmates and a strong teaching team
Yeah! It's a good class, professor is fun, Shakespeare can be dry but it's nice to get adaptations to see shakespeare in a modern lens.
YES!

Absolutely! It was fun, educational, enjoyable, and lovely!! I would recommend it to any student who needs a writing credit or wants to learn about Shakespeare in a fun, non-traditional, socially aware way.

Would absolutely recommend to anyone who is mildly interested in the classics, and to people who are looking for that one Humanities credit. The workload is not very heavy, and the assignment types can be quite diverse, so there is a lot of space to get creative.
yes - the material is interesting though the reading may be hard to keep up with
Yes, I thought the coursework was engaging and the lectures were fantastic.
This course was nice. Be prepared for a lot of work, but Prof. Ramachandran is great. I think that  taking this course outside of a pandemic year would be a better option.

Yes, absolutely. This is a great course for any student, regardless of whether you're majoring in the humanities. It is about more than just Shakespeare it's about how we approach the study of any text. Dr. R is an amazing professor, and the TA's are wonderful, too.

yes! Professor R is amazing and it was a great way to learn about Shakespeare while also critically questioning traditional intellectual orthodoxies and paradigms surrounding him as a canonical figure

Extremely informative class taught by an insanely talented, caring and dedicated professor. The course material is diverse and the topics in the course are very engaging with different lenses being adopted when looking at original Shakespeare plays and their adaptations. The class forces introspection on the nature of the traditional Western canon and our own relationship with such works. There are many materials to help one succeed in this class and the student's wellbeing and learning are of utmost priority to Prof.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: live lecture + section
live virtual lecture and live virtual discussion section, Discord
Discussion section weekly
We had a seminar once a week on zoom.
There was also a discord group where people in the class could hold discussions or otherwise interact
lectures were recorded
There was a live lecture followed by discussion sections during regular class hours. There was also discussion section
Weekly virtual section meeting.
live virtual lecture, virtual discussion section
There was also a virtual section meeting once a week in addition to the two virtual lectures
